content:
I've noticed that you can (seemingly rather canonically?) combine two monads by taking their pullback. Let TTT and UUU be monads. I believe the following pullback is also a monad:

pullback pointwise
or, applied to XXX:
applied to X

I've seen this pattern in @Egbert Rijke - @Mike Shulman - @Bas Spitters's "Modalities in HoTT", where ◯×♢∘◯♢\bigcirc \times_{♢ \circ \bigcirc} ♢◯×♢∘◯​♢ is written as the "join" ◯∨♢\bigcirc \lor ♢◯∨♢, and the [[fracture theorem]] says that (under some conditions) ◯∨♢=Id\bigcirc \lor ♢ = \text{Id}◯∨♢=Id.

I have recently found this construction to be useful in cases where the monads in question aren't idempotent, too. Is this construction studied (or even named/written down) anywhere else?

(I would assume so, but unfortunately looking up "monad join" and "monad pullback" lead me to other things!)

Wow, this is weird! I'll temporarily take your word for it that it works. I note it's not symmetrical in the two monads UUU and TTT, or at least it doesn't look like it. What's the pullback of (say) the monad for groups and the monad for groups?
I've always heard that monads don't compose, but to define pullback one must use composition?

John Baez said:

Wow, this is weird! I'll temporarily take your word for it that it works. I note it's not symmetrical in the two monads UUU and TTT, or at least it doesn't look like it. What's the pullback of (say) the monad for groups and the monad for groups?

Agreed, it's definitely not symmetric in UUU and TTT!

If TTT and UUU are both the free monoid monad Set→Set\mathbf{Set} \to \mathbf{Set}Set→Set, then I think the pullback should be the identity monad - an element would have to be a pair of lists (l1:List(X),l2:List(X))(l_1 : \text{List}(X), l_2 : \text{List}(X))(l1​:List(X),l2​:List(X)) such that [l1]=List([−])(l2)[l_1] = \text{List}([-])(l_2)[l1​]=List([−])(l2​), which I believe is equivalent to requiring that both l1l_1l1​ and l2l_2l2​ are equal singleton lists (with a single element of XXX) by injectivity of [−][-][−]. I think the free group monad should be the same story?

If TTT is the free group monad and UUU is some open modality on a topos (cf RSS), though, the story is more interesting - the pullback classifies group syntax that collapses in the open subtopos to a generator, eg strings like x1⋅x2−1⋅yx_1 \cdot x_2^{-1} \cdot yx1​⋅x2−1​⋅y that cancel to just yyy in the open subtopos (assuming x1=x2x_1 = x_2x1​=x2​ in the open subtopos).

Ryan Wisnesky said:

I've always heard that monads don't compose, but to define pullback one must use composition?

Right, I'm using U∘TU \circ TU∘T here, but I'm not assuming that it forms a monad! I'm just composing the endofunctors and using their composite to "connect" the two "components" of the pullback. (Or maybe this isn't what you're saying?)

It doesn't look like there's anything special about monads here... As we famously know, a monad is just a monoid in End(C)\text{End}(C)End(C), with it's (noncommutative!) monoidal structure coming from composition. If your observation works, it'll probably work at the level of "the pullback of monoids in a monoidal category along their tensor product is again a monoid"

That's something that might counterintuitively be easier to work out, because there's less baggage about monads and distributive laws (which I guess in this context are kind of like a braiding... I've never noticed that before!) hanging around

Harrison Grodin said:

I've noticed that you can (seemingly rather canonically?) combine two monads by taking their pullback. Let TTT and UUU be monads. I believe the following pullback is also a monad:

pullback pointwise
or, applied to XXX:
applied to X

I've seen this pattern in Egbert Rijke - Mike Shulman - Bas Spitters's "Modalities in HoTT", where ◯×◯∘♢♢\bigcirc \times_{\bigcirc \circ ♢} ♢◯×◯∘♢​♢ is written as the "join" ◯∨♢\bigcirc \lor ♢◯∨♢, and the [[fracture theorem]] says that (under some conditions) ◯∨♢=Id\bigcirc \lor ♢ = \text{Id}◯∨♢=Id.

I have recently found this construction to be useful in cases where the monads in question aren't idempotent, too. Is this construction studied (or even named/written down) anywhere else?

(I would assume so, but unfortunately looking up "monad join" and "monad pullback" lead me to other things!)

I would be surprised that it works without assuming that the pullback is preserved by TTT and/or UUU.

Same comment for pullbacks of monoids in a monoidal category. It should work with an assomption of the type “pullbacks are preserved by tensor product” or maybe just that the pullback of interest is preserved by tensoring by any of the two monoids on each side.
(I think you will need something like this when you try to prove associativity and unitality)

I would also be surprised if it works without any additional conditions.

But I've been surprised before.

(Sorry, yes, I should say that I haven't checked all of the conditions in detail! This construction seems to work in the cases I've checked, but I expect there are some conditions required in general.)
This topic was moved here from #learning: reading & references > Pullback of monads by Harrison Grodin.

I'm trying to work it out right now, and I agree: "flatness" of A and B (in the sense that tensoring with either preserves limits) seems necessary to even get started. But I don't have a full construction yet
@Sridhar Ramesh and I also have noticed this construction. It works for arbitrary monoids (assuming the pullback exists). I can upload an argument soon.

Here's an argument with string diagrams that was in my notes. Sorry if this is unreadable, I can translate it into words later.
uAK3gSxn.jpg
Red is T, blue is U, and purple is the relevant pullback. The grey nodes are the pullback projection maps. Points where wires merge/appear are the monoid multiplications/units.
We also see here that the projections are monoid homomorphisms.

Now with words:

For convenience denote by SSS the pullback of idT⊗ηU\mathrm{id}_T \otimes \eta_UidT​⊗ηU​ and ηT⊗idU\eta_T \otimes \mathrm{id}_UηT​⊗idU​, and denote by pT:S→Tp_T : S \to TpT​:S→T and pU:S→Up_U: S \to UpU​:S→U the projections.

For each nnn, we have an nnn-ary map tn:S⊗…⊗S→Tt_n : S \otimes \ldots \otimes S \to Ttn​:S⊗…⊗S→T obtained by composing pT⊗…⊗pTp_T \otimes \ldots \otimes p_TpT​⊗…⊗pT​ with the nnn-ary multiplication for TTT. Similarly, we have an nnn-ary map un:S⊗…⊗S→Uu_n : S \otimes \ldots \otimes S \to Uun​:S⊗…⊗S→U.

Hence we can form maps tn⊗um:S⊗…⊗S→T⊗Ut_n \otimes u_m: S \otimes \ldots \otimes S \to T \otimes Utn​⊗um​:S⊗…⊗S→T⊗U. Observe tn⊗um=tn′⊗um′t_n \otimes u_m = t_{n'} \otimes u_{m'}tn​⊗um​=tn′​⊗um′​ whenever n+m=n′+m′n + m = n' + m'n+m=n′+m′, by repeatedly introducing units and applying the defining equation for the pullback.

In particular, for each nnn,
tn;(idT⊗ηU)=tn⊗ηU=tn⊗u0=t0⊗un=ηT⊗un=un;(ηT⊗idU)t_n ; (\mathrm{id}_T \otimes \eta_U) = t_n \otimes \eta_U = t_n \otimes u_0 = t_0 \otimes u_n = \eta_T \otimes u_n = u_n ; (\eta_T \otimes \mathrm{id}_U)tn​;(idT​⊗ηU​)=tn​⊗ηU​=tn​⊗u0​=t0​⊗un​=ηT​⊗un​=un​;(ηT​⊗idU​).
By the universal property of the pullback, we thus obtain a unique map μn:S⊗…⊗S→S\mu_n: S \otimes \ldots \otimes S \to Sμn​:S⊗…⊗S→S such that μn;pT=tn\mu_n ; p_T = t_nμn​;pT​=tn​ and μn;pU=un\mu_n ; p_U = u_nμn​;pU​=un​. This will be the nnn-ary multiplication for SSS.

The nnn-ary associativity/unit laws say that every nnn-ary map S⊗…⊗S→SS \otimes \ldots \otimes S \to SS⊗…⊗S→S obtained as a tree composed of μi\mu_iμi​ maps is itself μn\mu_nμn​. Indeed, any such tree μn′\mu'_nμn′​ composed of μi\mu_iμi​ maps satisfies μn′;pT=tn\mu'_n ; p_T = t_nμn′​;pT​=tn​ and μn′;pU=un\mu'_n ; p_U = u_nμn′​;pU​=un​, using the associativity/unit laws for TTT and UUU, and so μn′=μn\mu'_n = \mu_nμn′​=μn​ by uniqueness of the pullback factoring map.
The proof idea came from @Sridhar Ramesh.

My brain hurts. It's hard to think about this because for the familiar case of monoids in Set (or any cartesian monoidal category), and I think also for monoids in Ab (i.e. rings), this pullback is always trivial. Are there any monoidal categories that are simpler than endofunctors in which this pullback is nontrivial?

Also, is this pullback ever nontrivial for monads on Set?

Trying to understand this some more... generalizing the example of the free group monad and the open modality, I think we can say that if UUU is a [[semi-left-exact reflection]], then the map T×U∘TU→TT\times_{U\circ T} U \to TT×U∘T​U→T is the right half of the UUU-factorization of the unit Id→T\mathrm{Id} \to TId→T.

The reason I was interested in this originally was from a conversation with Peter Selinger where we were just looking at the case of monads on Set and where T=1T = 1T=1, the terminal monad. So, we were looking at the pullback of η:1→U(1)\eta: 1 \to U(1)η:1→U(1) and U(!):U(X)→U(1)U(!): U(X) \to U(1)U(!):U(X)→U(1).

The new monad SSS created from this process satisfies S(1)=1S(1) = 1S(1)=1, and if U(1)=1U(1) = 1U(1)=1 already then we just get U=SU = SU=S.

From the powerset monad we get the "nonempty powerset" monad sending a set to the set of its nonempty subsets. As I think is being discussed by @Harrison Grodin and @Mike Shulman in greater generality (but I don't yet understand that level of generality), from the free group monad we get a monad corresponding to an algebraic theory where the operations are group words such that the number of inverted letters is one less than the number of non-inverted letters.

Aaron David Fairbanks said:

The new monad SSS created from this process satisfies S(1)=1S(1) = 1S(1)=1, and if U(1)=1U(1) = 1U(1)=1 already then we just get U=SU = SU=S.

I don't suppose this happens to be the cofree [[affine monad]] on UUU?
What's an affine monad?
One that preserves the terminal object.
Presumably this forms a monoidal structure, whose unit is the unit monad. What do the monoids with respect to this monoidal structure look like?

Nathanael Arkor said:

I don't suppose this happens to be the cofree [[affine monad]] on UUU?

Yes, I think so.
@Aaron David Fairbanks: was this something you were plannning to write up? It would be nice to have a reference for this construction in the literature.
Hmm, maybe! I wonder if just this is enough to make a paper about. What do you think @Sridhar Ramesh?

Papers do not need to be very long :) And I think there are enough things to say:

  • The construction itself.
  • Some examples.
  • The connection with the cofree affine monad (and, ideally, more generally a universal property).
  • Perhaps whether this forms a monoidal structure (and, if so, how it interacts with the original monoidal structure).
Sure, let's do it, @Aaron David Fairbanks. It would be fun to write together. If it finds a home in a journal, great, and if nothing else, we'll put it on arXiv.
I wonder whether the construction works more generally for enriched categories (generalising monoids in V\mathcal VV as one-object V\mathcal VV-categories) :thinking:
Or more generally with "incoherent bimonoids" and the cotensor product of comonoids ...

Nathanael Arkor said:

I wonder whether the construction works more generally for enriched categories (generalising monoids in V\mathcal VV as one-object V\mathcal VV-categories) :thinking:

(Well, if the set of objects are the same, then it should be a special case of the construction for monoids, considering monads in V-Dist\mathcal V\text{-Dist}V-Dist.)
It also looks to me like the proof works for monoids in a multicategory: I only see that you need the tensor product of the SSS and UUU, and not of anything else.
Thanks @Nathanael Arkor. We will try to make this happen. Yes, I also prefer thinking about it in terms of multicategories.
